vehicles.name: Corp Executive AV
vehicles.desc: The board-level aerial vehicle. She carries C-suite executives between arcologies, negotiation sites, and the rooftop helipads of buildings that touch the clouds. She's armoured against assassination, equipped for surveillance, and luxurious enough to close deals at altitude.
vehicles.notes: The executive AV is the corporate throne room. Meetings happen inside her while she circles the city. She represents power — whoever controls the AV controls the meeting. Use her for corporate intrigue scenarios where the vehicle is the neutral ground.

vehicles.name: Street Racer
vehicles.desc: Stolen chassis, illegal engine modifications, and software that overclocks every system past the manufacturer's safety limits. She's the weapon of choice for go-gangs and street racers who consider traffic fatalities a spectator sport.
vehicles.notes: The street racer variant leans into criminal modification. She's faster than the starter version but less reliable — the overclocked systems fail more often. Use her for illegal street racing campaigns and go-gang encounters.

vehicles.name: Tactical Drone Swarm
vehicles.desc: Not one drone but dozens — a coordinated cloud of micro-platforms that think collectively, attack from every direction, and reform around losses like a flock of mechanical birds. Individually harmless. Collectively, they strip the flesh from a target in seconds.
vehicles.notes: The drone swarm is your horror-tech weapon. She can't be fought conventionally — shooting individual drones is pointless. Area-effect weapons, EMP, and hacking the swarm controller are the counters. Use her for the terrifying moment when the air fills with tiny machines.

vehicles.name: Armoured Riot Van
vehicles.desc: Heavy corporate security vehicle deployed when the street protests escalate beyond what foot patrols can handle. She carries suppression weapons, detention cells, and a broadcast system that declares martial law in the corporate zone.
vehicles.notes: The fleet riot van variant is heavier than the starter version. She carries detention pods for mass arrest. Use her for dystopian scenarios where corporate security is indistinguishable from military occupation.

vehicles.name: Courier Bike
vehicles.desc: A stripped-down electric bike optimised for the last mile of delivery through streets that autonomous vehicles can't navigate. She weaves through crowds, she jumps barriers, and her rider knows the alleyways that don't appear on any map.
vehicles.notes: The fleet courier bike is your street-level mission vehicle. She gets through obstacles that stop larger vehicles. Her rider's knowledge of the city is as important as the bike's speed. Use her for data-running missions through contested neighbourhoods.

vehicles.name: Merc APC
vehicles.desc: Private military transport. She carries a fire team of corporate contractors with military-grade augmentations and no accountability to anyone but the company that signs the cheques. She arrives when the corporation decides negotiation has failed.
vehicles.notes: The fleet merc APC is your corporate military escalation. She represents the moment when corporate security becomes corporate warfare. Her crew are professionals with combat augmentations — they're tougher than regular security.

vehicles.name: Spider Tank
vehicles.desc: Autonomous heavy weapons platform. She walks through urban canyons on six articulated legs, her weapons tracking multiple targets simultaneously, her AI making engagement decisions faster than any human crew could. She is law enforcement at its most inhuman.
vehicles.notes: The fleet spider tank variant emphasises AI autonomy. She makes her own targeting decisions, which means she can be fooled by spoofed IFF signals or confused by civilian crowds that her ethics subroutine won't let her fire into. Exploit the AI's rules.

vehicles.name: Hacker Van
vehicles.desc: A nondescript delivery van packed with server racks, antenna arrays, and enough processing power to crack corporate encryption from a parking spot. She's the mobile command post for netrunner teams who prefer to hack from close range.
vehicles.notes: The hacker van is your netrunner base of operations. She needs to be close to the target network for maximum bandwidth. She's defenceless physically — the netrunner inside relies on the street team to protect the van while they work.

vehicles.name: Cargo Drone
vehicles.desc: Heavy-lift autonomous drone carrying standardised cargo containers between distribution centres. She's part of a fleet of thousands that fills the sky with commerce. Nobody notices one more cargo drone — which is exactly what the smugglers are counting on.
vehicles.notes: The fleet cargo drone is your infiltration tool. Hack her routing, replace her cargo, and she delivers contraband directly to the target building. She's the perfect Trojan horse for a world that runs on automated delivery.

vehicles.name: Luxury Hover-Limo
vehicles.desc: The ultimate expression of corporate wealth — anti-gravity suspension, ablative armour beneath the chrome finish, and an interior that costs more than most people earn in a lifetime. She floats above the world she profits from and her passengers never look down.
vehicles.notes: The hover-limo is your rolling exposition vehicle. The passengers are the rich, the powerful, and the morally compromised. Use her for high-society infiltration, assassinations, and the moment when the players realise the person they're protecting is worse than the people trying to kill them.
